awd_titl_txt: A Study in Engaging Students with Complex Topics through Knowledge Graphs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving sustainability science instruction and learning at a general education level for undergraduate students. Educating future generations about sustainability science is a critical problem for humanity’s collective future. Recognizing the importance of this topic, many colleges and universities have established or are developing general education courses on sustainability science that every student must take. This project will improve undergraduate STEM education by developing and studying the effectiveness of educational modules that engage students from many different majors with sustainability science and helping them grapple with the complexity of the topic. It is based on the key observation that knowledge graphs, an emerging means of storing information computationally, provide a potential way to span across disciplines and unpack complexity one layer at a time. They allow students to engage with problems that more accurately represent the challenges of sustainability science than traditional techniques. The contributions of the project include: (1) a new knowledge graph-based approach to supporting student learning of concepts in sustainability science that addresses a critical shortcoming in the sustainability education landscape; (2) assessments of this approach in terms of engagement and efficacy at helping students learn key concepts in sustainability; and (3) a publicly available computational scaffolding for this technique.

The central goal of the project is to assess three core research questions: (1) Can knowledge graph-based educational modules help students improve their understanding of sustainability concepts within and across fields? (2) Can student contributions to a shared knowledge graph form a useful foundation for later pedagogical activities? (3) Can students contribute accurate and relevant sustainability information to a global, public knowledge graph through their coursework? The team will investigate these questions by developing a novel computational platform for education and deploying it with more than 2,000 students across two universities. The platform developed as part of this grant will enable students to make their own knowledge graphs based on course content and integrate their graphs with those of their peers, as well as complete further activities based on revising the collective graph. Assessment will involve both quantitative and qualitative evaluations of the course modules and their effect on student learning, as well as computational analyses of the collectively-constructed graph. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this research project was to develop and evaluate a suite of educational modules to help undergraduate students learn about sustainability science in a General Education (GE) context.  To do so, we developed a set of assignments for those courses, a software system based on the concept of a computational knowledge graph to support those assignments, and a set of processes for evaluating the effectiveness of the assignments. A secondary goal was to enable the output from student work on these assignments to be added to Wikidata, a public, open knowledge graph. We succeeded in both of these goals.

With regard to the educational goal: we developed, deployed, and evaluated multiple versions of the relevant assignments, and implemented a system called ZotGraph to provide computational support for them.  We deployed the ZotGraph system in seven undergraduate course offerings (five offerings of "ICS5: Global Disruption and Information Technology" and two of "ESS1: Introduction to Earth System Science), contributing to the education of a total of approximately 2000 students across the three years of the grant. Both courses using this system were effective in engaging students with sustainability concepts, showing improvement in students’ nature relatedness and environmental concern.

With regard to the impact on Wikidata: we developed a pipeline by which student-generated content could be contributed to Wikidata.  This pipeline involved collecting the products of student work in the form of concepts and relationships in a format that matched Wikidata, and then enabling an expert to vet those contributions to ensure their accuracy.  As a result of the student work described above, the team uploaded 402 statements to Wikidata, connecting 412 concepts on that site.

In addition, this support from NSF allowed us to explore potential extensions to this project and related topics, including both technological domains (e.g., generative AI) and environmental concerns (e.g., biodiversity loss).

Intellectual Merit: Across all the work conducted through funding by this grant, our team produced nineteen scholarly publications, including research in computing, sustainability education, as well as other fields, and delivered an array of public presentations on aspects of this work.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the proposed work are three-fold: approximately 2,000 students educated in sustainability science; expanded opportunities for broader participation in STEM, since UCI is a federally-designated Hispanic-Serving Institution; and multiple contributions to a public knowledge base of sustainability information to the Wikidata platform.
